title:
Construction of Quasi-periodic solutions with the same Gevrey index as
  nonlinear terms in Multi-Dimensional NLS

sections.text:
#### Abstract

We investigate the persistency of quasi-periodic solutions to multi-dimensional nonlinear Schrödinger equations (NLS) involving Gevrey smooth nonlinearity with an arbitrary Gevrey index $\alpha>1$. By applying the Craig-Wayne-Bourgain (CWB) method, we establish the existence of quasi-periodic solutions that are Gevrey smooth with the same Gevrey index as the nonlinearity.


Keywords: Quasi-periodic solutions, Gevrey class, NLS, Craig-Wayne-Bourgain method, KAM

# 1 Introduction 

In this paper, we consider the persistency of quasi-periodic solutions of the multi-dimensional nonlinear Schrödinger equation (NLS):

$$
\frac{1}{i} q_{t}(\tilde{x}, t)=-\Delta q(\tilde{x}, t)+V(\tilde{x}) * q(\tilde{x}, t)+\varepsilon \frac{\partial H}{\partial \tilde{q}}(q, \tilde{q})
$$

under periodic boundary conditions (i.e., $\tilde{x} \in \mathbb{T}^{d}$ ). The convolution potential $V: \mathbb{T}^{d} \rightarrow \mathbb{C}$ has real Fourier coefficients $\hat{V}(n), n \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}$. The Hamiltonian $H(q, \tilde{q})=f(q \tilde{q})$, where $f: \mathbb{R} \rightarrow \mathbb{R}$, belongs to the Gevrey class. In other words, we are intended to prove a Kolmogorov-ArnoldMoser (KAM) theorem for equation (1.1).

When $d=1$, the KAM theory of Hamiltonian PDEs is well established; see, for instance, [Kuk87], [KP96], [Way90], [Kuk93], [P96] and [CW93]. This equation is intrinsically interesting, when the spatial dimension $d \geq 2$. However, the study of KAM theory for Hamiltonian PDEs with $d \geq 2$ remains in its early stages. For $d=2$, [Bou98] developed a new method initialed by [CW93] to obtain the Gevrey smooth quasi-periodic solutions of NLS with analytic nonlinearity. His method relies on Newton iteration, Fröhlich-Spencer techniques (i.e., multi-scale analysis), and the Malgrange preparation theorem. Later, [Bou05] introduced harmonic analysis and semialgebraic set theory to refine the techniques in [Bou98], proving the persistency of quasi-periodic solutions of NLS and NLW with analytic nonlinearity for arbitrary $d$, and he claimed the obtained solutions are analytic. However, he only gave a sketch of the proof, and there is a key coupling lemma seems unlikely to hold. We believe the sketch he described there can only obtain the Gevrey smooth solutions. This method is now referred to as the Craig-Wayne-Bourgain (CWB) method.

For the case of finitely differentiable nonlinearity, Berti, Bolle, Corsi, and Procesi among others, ([BB10], [BBP10], [BP11], [BB12], [BB13], [BCP15], and [BB20], for example), improved the Nash-Moser iterative scheme and developed a novel multi-scale inductive analysis. They established the existence of finitely differentiable periodic or quasi-periodic solutions for NLS and NLW with finitely differentiable nonlinearity for arbitrary spatial dimension $d$.

In this paper, we aim to show that for (1.1) with Gevrey nonlinearity, most quasi-periodic solutions persist and the persisted solutions have the same Gevrey index as the nonlinearity. To state our results, we begin with the definition of a Gevrey- $(\alpha, L)$ function. Let $\alpha>1, L>0$, and let $K$ be a compact set of the form $K^{\prime} \times \mathbb{T}^{n_{2}}$, where $K^{\prime} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}$ is compact, and $n_{1}+n_{2} \geq 1$. We define

$$
G^{\alpha, L}(K)=\left\{\varphi \in C^{\infty}(K):\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L}=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{N}^{n_{1}+n_{2}}}\left(\frac{L^{|k|_{1}}}{k!}\right)^{\alpha}\left\|\partial^{k} \varphi\right\|_{C^{0}(K)}<\infty\right\}
$$

where $|k|_{1}=\sum_{j=1}^{n_{1}+n_{2}}\left|k_{j}\right|, k!=\prod_{j=1}^{n_{1}+n_{2}} k_{j}!$, and $\left\|\cdot\right\|_{C^{0}(K)}$ denotes the uniform norm for continuous functions defined on $K$. A function $\varphi \in G^{\alpha, L}(K)$ is called a Gevrey- $(\alpha, L)$ function. We refer to $\alpha$ as the Gevrey index and $L$ as the Gevrey width of $\varphi$. Furthermore, we define

$$
G^{\alpha}(K)=\underset{L>0}{\cup} G^{\alpha, L}(K)
$$

and functions in $G^{\alpha}(K)$ are referred as Gevrey- $\alpha$ functions. We assume $f, f^{\prime}, f^{\prime \prime} \in G^{\alpha, L_{0}}([-1,1])$ for some $\alpha>1$ and $L_{0}>0$.

One says $\tilde{q}(\tilde{x}, t)$ is a quasi-periodic function in time $t$ if there exist $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}^{b}$ and $q(\tilde{x}, \theta) \in$ $L^{2}\left(\mathbb{T}^{d+b}\right)$ (here $\tilde{x} \in \mathbb{T}^{d}, \theta \in \mathbb{T}^{b}$ ) such that

$$
\tilde{q}(\tilde{x}, t)=q(\tilde{x}, \lambda t)
$$

We say that $\lambda$ is the frequency and $q(\tilde{x}, \theta)$ is the hull of $\tilde{q}(\tilde{x}, t)$. See [KP96] for the definitions of quasi-periodic function and its hull, for example.

Select finite Fourier modes $0 \in\left\{n_{1}, n_{2}, \ldots, n_{b}\right\} \subset \mathbb{Z}^{d}$. Denote $\mathcal{R}=\left\{\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right): 1 \leq j \leq b\right\}$, where $e_{j}$ is the $j$-th unit vector in $\mathbb{Z}^{b}$. Let $\operatorname{supp} \hat{V}=\left\{n_{1}, \ldots, n_{b}\right\}$. Then, the spectral of the operator $\mathcal{L}:=-\Delta+V(\tilde{x}) *$ are

$$
\begin{cases}\mu_{n_{j}}=\lambda_{j}, & (1 \leq j \leq b) \\ \mu_{n}=|n|^{2} & n \in \mathbb{Z}^{d} \backslash\left\{n_{1}, \ldots, n_{b}\right\}\end{cases}
$$

where $|n|^{2}=\sum_{j=1}^{d}\left|n_{j}\right|^{2}$ and $\lambda:=\left(\lambda_{j}=\left|n_{j}\right|^{2}+\hat{V}\left(n_{j}\right): 1 \leq j \leq b\right)$. Given $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{b} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$,

$$
\tilde{q}_{0}(\tilde{x}, t)=q_{0}(\tilde{x}, \lambda t)=\sum_{j=1}^{b} a_{j} e^{i \lambda_{j} t+i n_{j} \cdot \tilde{x}}
$$

yields a solution to the linear equation

$$
\frac{1}{i} q_{t}(\tilde{x}, t)=-\Delta q(\tilde{x}, t)+V(\tilde{x}) * q(\tilde{x}, t)
$$

This solution is quasi-periodic and corresponds to a flow on a $b$-torus

$$
\mathbb{T}^{b}=\mathcal{T}_{0}\left\{\left|a_{j}\right|\right\}=\left\{\sum_{j=1}^{b} z_{j} e^{i n_{j} \cdot \tilde{x}}: z_{j} \in \mathbb{C},\left|z_{j}\right|=a_{j}\right\}
$$

The problem we study is the "persistency" of solutions (1.5) for the Gevrey perturbed equation (1.1). The term "persistency" in this paper is defined as follows:

There exists a quasi-periodic solution

$$
\tilde{q}(\tilde{x}, t)=q\left(\tilde{x}, \lambda^{\prime} t\right)
$$

to (1.1), such that

$$
\left|\lambda^{\prime}-\lambda\right|<C \varepsilon
$$

and

$$
\left\|q-q_{0}\right\|_{\alpha, L^{\prime}}<C \varepsilon
$$

for some $L^{\prime}>0$. Here, $C$ is a constant depending only on $b, d, L_{0}, \alpha$ and the bound of $\lambda$.
Note that the Gevrey index $\alpha>1$ of the solutions here is the same as the Gevrey index of nonlinearity, and $\alpha>1$ is arbitrary. In previous papers, the persisted solutions only have Gevrey index $\alpha \gg 1$, even if the nonlinearity is polynomial.

In KAM theory, the vector $\left(\hat{V}\left(n_{j}\right): 1 \leq j \leq b\right)$ is typically considered as a parameter vector. This is equivalent to regarding $\lambda=\left(\lambda_{1}, \ldots, \lambda_{b}\right)$ in the same way. Thus, we take $\lambda \in I_{0}=[0,1]^{b}$ as parameters.

Here is our main theorem.
Theorem 1.1. For arbitrary $\alpha>1$, let $H(q, \bar{q})=f(q \bar{q}), f, f^{\prime}, f^{\prime \prime} \in G^{\alpha, L_{0}}([-1,1])\left(L_{0}>0\right)$. Fix $a_{1}, \ldots, a_{b} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}$and let $I_{0}=[0,1]^{b}$. For $\varepsilon$ sufficiently small, there exists a Cantor set $I_{0, \varepsilon} \subset I_{0}$ such that $\operatorname{mes}\left(I_{0} \backslash I_{0, \varepsilon}\right) \rightarrow 0$ as $\varepsilon \rightarrow 0$. For $\lambda \in I_{0, \varepsilon}$, there exists a quasi-periodic solution to (1.1) with frequency $\lambda^{\prime}$ (depending on $\lambda$ ), whose hull $q(\tilde{x}, \theta)$ is in $G^{\alpha, L_{0} / 2}\left(\mathbb{T}^{d+b}\right)$. Moreover, we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\hat{q}\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)=a_{j}, \quad 1 \leq j \leq b \\
\left|\lambda^{\prime}-\lambda\right| \leq C \varepsilon
\end{gathered}
$$

$$
\sum_{\substack{(n, k) \in \mathbb{Z}^{d+k} \\(n, k) \notin \mathcal{R}}}\|\hat{q}(n, k)\| e^{\frac{\alpha k n}{2}|(n, k)|_{\alpha}} \leq C \varepsilon
$$

which implies

$$
\left\|q-q_{0}\right\|_{\alpha, \frac{k_{\alpha}}{2}}<C \varepsilon
$$

where $\hat{q}(n, k)$ is the $(n, k)$-Fourier coefficient of $q(\tilde{x}, \theta), q_{0}(\tilde{x}, \theta)=\sum_{j=1}^{h} a_{j} e^{i \theta_{j}+i n_{j} \cdot \tilde{x}}$, and $C$ is a constant depending on $\alpha, L_{0}, I_{0}, b$ and $d$ only.

Here, the term $|(n, k)|_{\alpha}=\sum_{j=1}^{d}\left|n_{j}\right|^{1 / \alpha}+\sum_{j=1}^{d}\left|k_{j}\right|^{1 / \alpha}$, and the weight function $e^{\alpha L^{\prime}|(n, k)|_{\alpha}}$ corresponds to Gevrey- $\left(\alpha, L^{\prime}\right)$ regularity.

The following are some key highlights that we would like to emphasize:
In this paper, we propose a new approach based on the Craig-Wayne-Bourgain (CWB) method to handle Gevrey smooth nonlinear perturbations. Unlike earlier works, which approximated the Gevrey Hamiltonian by analytic ones (see [Pop04] for example), we directly employ the Gevrey norm introduced in [MS02] (i.e., (1.2)). We find that the Gevrey norm possesses an almost equivalent norm described by Fourier coefficients, allowing us to use it similarly to the sup-norm of real analytic functions in most cases.

To apply the semi-algebraic techniques, we explored the relationship between the rate of polynomial approximation of Gevrey functions in Gevrey norm and the domain, and developed an effective strategy for the polynomial approximation of Gevrey funtions.

During the Newton iteration, we need to estimate the Gevrey norm of the approximate solution $q\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$. We apply the Markov Inequality to obtain the Gevrey norm estimate of $q\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$ only from the sup-norm of $T_{r-1}^{-1}\left(\eta, \eta^{\prime}\right)$ and $F\left(q_{r}\right)$ on a real domain.

In addition, as we have mentioned in the beginning, Bourgain only provided an outline of the proof of the persistency of quasi-periodic solutions for NLS and NLW using the CWB method in Chapters 19 and 20 of [Bou05]. There is a key coupling lemma in his argument, but he did not give a proof for this coupling lemma. The coupling lemma he claimed seems unlikely to hold, as noted by [Wan16], "This is because the sizes of the resonant clusters are in general, much larger than their separation." In our paper, we exploit the strict concavity of $g(s)=s^{1 / \alpha}$ to improve Lemma 7 of [Bou98] and obtain our Lemma 6.1. In Lemma 7 of [Bou98], the loss of the decay rate is $\frac{1}{2} L$, while the loss of the decay rate in Lemma 6.1 can be arbitrarily small. This improvement helps us to get solutions with arbitrary Gevrey index $\alpha>1$.

Moreover, when applying the CWB method, the reality of the drifted frequency $\lambda^{\prime}$ is straightforward when the nonlinearity is polynomial or real analytic. However, for Gevrey smooth nonlinearity, the reality of the drifted frequency $\lambda^{\prime}$ seems not to be obvious. We provide a proposition in Appendix A to clarify this issue.

Here are more remarks.
Remark 1. It seems that the scheme in the present paper could apply to NLW by combining with Lemma 20.14 in [Bou05].

Remark 2. Typically, when $d=1$, the second Melnikov conditions hold, and the solutions obtained from the classical KAM techniques are linearly stable. However, the linear stability of solutions obtained from CWB method is unknown. In 2010, [EK10] applied classical KAM techniques to prove the KAM theorem for NLS with analytic nonlinearity for arbitrary d, obtaining KAM tori that are analytic in time and $C^{\infty}$ in space. For $d \geq 1$, Yuan/Yua21] proved the KAM theorem for the generalized Pochhammer-Chree equations using the traditional KAM techniques,

and the obtained KAM tori are also linearly stable. Recently, He, J. Shi, Y. Shi and Yuan [HSSY24] proved the the linear stability of the KAM tori without the second Melnikov conditions by combining the traditional KAM techniques and the CWB method. Thus, it seems plausible that the solutions here are also linearly stable.

Remark 3. If we apply the amplitude-frequency modulation, as in [Bou95], [KP96], [PP12], [Wan19], [BB20], etc, we could replace the convolution potential $V(\tilde{x}) *$ by the multiplicative potential $V(\tilde{x}) \equiv$ constant. However, for the simplicity of the argument, we do not pursue this in the present work.

Remark 4. For more history and applications of the CWB method to Hamiltonian PDEs, we refer to [CW93], [Bou94],[Bou95], [Bou97], [Bou98], [Wan16], [Wan19], [Wan20].

Notations. For $a, b \in \mathbb{R}^{d}$, we denote by $a \cdot b$ the standard product in $R^{d}$. The symbol $\|\cdot\|$ denotes $l^{2}$ norm, $L^{2}$ norm or the operator norm corresponding to these norms.

Let $K$ be a compact set, and $\varphi \in C(K)$. We denote the uniform norm of $\varphi$ by $\|\varphi\|_{C^{0}(K)}$.
Let $C^{k}(K)$ be the set of $k$-times continuously differentiable complex-valued functions.

$$
|k|=\max _{i=1, \ldots, n}\left\{\left|k_{i}\right|\right\}, \quad|L|=\max _{i=1, \ldots, n}\left\{\left|L_{i}\right|\right\}, \quad|k|_{\alpha}=\sum_{i=1}^{n}\left|k_{i}\right|^{\frac{1}{d}}, \quad \boldsymbol{L}^{k}=\prod_{i=1}^{n}\left|L_{i}\right|^{k_{i}}
$$

Let $\left\{x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{k}\right\} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$. We denote by $\left[x_{1}, x_{2}, \ldots, x_{k}\right]$ the subspace spanned by these vectors. If we use $k_{1}$ to denote an element in $\mathbb{N}^{n}$, we use $k_{1}(j)$ to denote the j -th component of $k_{1}$, and the same convention applies to elements in $\mathbb{R}^{n}$. When we say $I \in \mathbb{R}^{n}$ is an interval of size $d$, we mean that $I$ is a closed cube with sides parallel to the axes, and each side has length $d$. Two intervals are said to be disjoint if their interiors are disjoint.

Let $I$ be an interval. We denote by $C I$ the interval with the same center as $I$ but expanded by the factor $C$.

Whenever we encounter a situation where a specific integer cannot be found, we will choose the closest integer.

For any positive numbers $a, b$ the notation $a \lesssim b$ means $C a \leq b$ for some constant $C>0$ depending only on $\alpha, L_{0}, I_{0}, b$ and $d$. By $a \ll b$ we mean that the constant $C$ is very large. The various constants can be defined by the context in which they arise. Finally, $N^{a-}$ means $N^{a-\epsilon}$ with some small $\epsilon>0$ (the precise meaning of "small" can again be derived from the context).

This paper is organized as follows: In Section 2, we provide the definitions of Gevrey functions, the Gevrey norm, and the properties of the Gevrey norm. Section 3 and Section 4 describe the Lyapounov-Schimidt decomposition and the Newton iteration scheme. In Section 5, we state the Iterative Lemma and provide its proof, except for the measure estimates. Notably, we demonstrate that the estimate of the Gevrey norm can be obtained at each step by applying polynomial truncation and the Markov Inequality. In Section 6, we present the proof of the measure estimates in the Iterative Lemma. In Section 7, we give the proof of Theorem 1.1. Finally, Appendices A and B present two technical propositions, Appendix C states the matrixvalued Cartan-type theorem, Appendix D states some facts about semialgebraic sets, Appendix E presents the multi-scale reasoning for the large deviation theorem.

# 2 Gevrey functions and their properties 

In this section, we provide the definition of Gevrey functions and some technical lemmas. In the Introduction, we have introduced the definition of a Gevrey- $(\alpha, L)$ function for $L>0$. Here, we extend the definition by defining the Gevrey norm with different Gevrey widths. Let $\boldsymbol{L} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n}$

and let $K$ be a compact set in $n$-dimensional space. For $\varphi \in C^{\infty}(K)$, the Gevrey norm is defined as follows:

$$
\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{N}^{n}}\left(\frac{\boldsymbol{L}^{k}}{k!}\right)^{\alpha}\left\|\partial^{k} \varphi\right\|_{C^{0}(K)}
$$

If $\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}<\infty$, we say that $\varphi$ is Gevrey- $(\alpha, \boldsymbol{L})$ on $K$, denoted by $\varphi \in G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}(K)$. The vector $\boldsymbol{L}$ is referred to as the Gevrey width of $\varphi$. We also have

$$
G^{\alpha}(K)=\bigcup_{\boldsymbol{L} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n}} G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}(K)
$$

In this paper, we frequently employ two distinct Gevrey widths. For clarity, we restate the definition in this context.

Let $n_{1}, n_{2} \in \mathbb{N}$ and $n=n_{1}+n_{2}$. Let $K_{1}$ be a compact interval in $\mathbb{R}^{n_{1}}$ (corresponding to parameters) and $K_{2}=\mathbb{T}^{n_{2}}$. Let $K=K_{1} \times K_{2}$ and $L_{1}, L_{2}>0$. For a function $\varphi(\lambda, \theta) \in C^{\infty}(K)$, where $\lambda \in K_{1}$ and $\theta \in K_{2}$, the Gevrey norm is defined as

$$
\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}=\sum_{k_{1} \in \mathbb{N}^{n_{1}}, k_{2} \in \mathbb{N}^{n_{2}}}\left(\frac{L_{1}^{\left|k_{1}\right|_{1}^{\alpha}} L_{2}^{\left|k_{2}\right|_{1}}}{k_{1}\left|k_{2}\right|}\right)^{\alpha}\left\|\partial_{\lambda}^{k_{1}} \partial_{\theta}^{k_{2}} \varphi\right\|_{C^{0}(K)}
$$

If $\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}<\infty$, we say that $\varphi(\lambda, \theta)$ is Gevrey- $\left(\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}\right)$ on $K$, denoted by $\varphi \in G^{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}(K)$. The parameters $L_{1}$ and $L_{2}$ are referred to the Gevrey widths with respect to $\lambda$ and $\theta$, respectively.

Proposition 2.1 (Product). Let $\boldsymbol{L} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{n}$ and $\varphi, \psi \in G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}(K)$, then we have

$$
\|\varphi \psi\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}} \leq\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}\|\psi\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}
$$

In particular, for $L_{1}, L_{2}>0$ and $\varphi, \psi \in G^{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}(K)$, we have

$$
\|\varphi \psi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}} \leq\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}\|\psi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}
$$

This proposition shows that $G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}$ is a Banach algebra.
Proposition 2.2 (Derivative). Suppose $0 \leq \boldsymbol{h}<\boldsymbol{L}$ and $\varphi \in G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}(K)$. Then all partial derivatives of $\varphi$ belong to $G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}-\boldsymbol{h}}(K)$, and we have

$$
\sum_{m \in \mathbb{N}^{n}} \frac{\boldsymbol{h}^{m \alpha}}{m!^{\alpha}}\left\|\partial^{m} \varphi\right\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}-\boldsymbol{h}} \leq\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}
$$

In particular, for all $m \in \mathbb{N}^{n}$,

$$
\left\|\partial^{m} \varphi\right\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}-\boldsymbol{h}} \leq\left(\frac{m!}{\boldsymbol{h}^{m}}\right)^{\alpha}\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}
$$

This result is often referred to as the "Cauchy estimate" for Gevrey functions.
Proposition 2.3 (Composition). Let $L>0, \boldsymbol{L} \in \mathbb{R}_{+}^{m}$, and let $K$ be an $n$-dimensional compact set, and $K_{1}$ be an m-dimensional compact set as previously defined. Let $Y \in G^{\alpha, L}(K)$, and let $u=\left(u_{1}, \ldots, u_{n}\right)$ be a mapping whose components belong to $G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}\left(K_{1}\right)$. If $u\left(K_{1}\right) \subset K$ and

$$
\left\|u_{j}\right\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}-\left\|u_{j}\right\|_{C^{0}\left(K_{1}\right)} \leq \frac{L^{\alpha}}{m^{\alpha-1}}, \quad 1 \leq j \leq n
$$

then $Y \circ u \in G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}\left(K_{1}\right)$ and $\|Y \circ u\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}} \leq\|Y\|_{\alpha, L}$.

The proofs of Proposition 2.1, 2.2 and 2.3 follow the same approaches as in [MS02], except for the allowance of different Gevrey widths in this context. For detailed proofs, we refer to [MS02].

We now discuss the decay of Fourier coefficients of Gevrey functions. Let $\alpha>1$ and $K=\mathbb{T}^{d}$. Lemma 4.8 in [DG17] shows that if $f \in G^{\alpha, L}\left(\mathbb{T}^{d}\right)$, then $|\hat{f}(k)| \leq C\|f\|_{\alpha, L} e^{-L|k|_{1}^{1 / \alpha}}$, where $C$ is a constant independent of $\alpha$ and $L$. However, with a minor modification to the proof, we can deduce a more intrinsic description:

Proposition 2.4 (Decay of Fourier coefficients). Let $\alpha>1$ and $L>0$. If $f \in G^{\alpha, L}\left(\mathbb{T}^{d}\right)$, then for any $k \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}$, we have

$$
|\hat{f}(k)| \leq\left(\frac{h(\varepsilon, \alpha)}{2 \pi}\right)^{d}\|f\|_{\alpha, L} e^{-\alpha(1-\varepsilon) L|k|_{\alpha}}
$$

where $h(\varepsilon, \alpha)=\left(\frac{1}{1-(1-\varepsilon)^{\frac{1}{n-1}}}\right)^{\alpha-1}$.
Proof. Since for any $\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}$, we have $\left|\left(\partial^{\beta} f\right)^{\wedge}(k)\right| \leq \frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\left\|\partial^{\beta} f\right\|_{C^{0}(K)}$, it follows that

$$
(2 \pi)^{d} \sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \frac{L^{|\beta| \iota \alpha}}{\beta!\alpha}\left|\left(\partial^{\beta} f\right)^{\wedge}(k)\right| \leq \sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \frac{L^{|\beta| \iota \alpha}}{\beta!\alpha}\left\|\partial^{\beta} f\right\|_{C^{0}(K)}=\|f\|_{\alpha, L}
$$

Thus, since $\left(\partial^{\beta} f\right)^{\wedge}(k)=(i k)^{\beta} \hat{f}(k)$, we obtain

$$
(2 \pi)^{d}|\hat{f}(k)| \sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \frac{L^{|\beta| \iota \alpha}}{\beta!\alpha} k^{\beta} \leq\|f\|_{\alpha, L}
$$

Therefore, it suffices to estimate

$$
\sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \frac{L^{|\beta| \iota \alpha}}{\beta!\alpha} k^{\beta}
$$

Notice that

$$
\sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \frac{L^{|\beta| \iota \alpha}}{\beta!\alpha} k^{\beta}=\prod_{j=1}^{d} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{L^{n \alpha}}{n!^{\alpha}}|k_{j}|^{\alpha}
$$

We now consider

$$
\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{L^{n \alpha}}{n!^{\alpha}}\left|k_{j}\right|^{n}=\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{\left(L\left|k_{j}\right|^{1 / \alpha}\right)^{n}}{n!}\right)^{\alpha}
$$

By Hölder inequality, we have

$$
\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} x_{n} y_{n}\right)^{\alpha} \leq\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} y_{n}^{\prime}\right)^{\frac{\alpha}{n}} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} x_{n}^{\alpha}
$$

where $\frac{1}{\alpha}+\frac{1}{t}=1$. Taking $x_{n}=\frac{\left(L\left|k_{j}\right|^{1 / \alpha}\right)^{n}}{n!}$ and $y_{n}=(1-\varepsilon)^{n}$, we have

$$
\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\left[(1-\varepsilon) L\left|k_{j}\right|^{1 / \alpha}\right]^{n}}{n!}\right)^{\alpha} \leq\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(1-\varepsilon)^{t n}\right)^{\alpha / t} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{L^{n \alpha}}{n!^{\alpha}}\left|k_{j}\right|^{n}
$$

Denote $h(\varepsilon, \alpha)=\left(\sum_{n=0}^{\infty}(1-\varepsilon)^{t n}\right)^{\alpha / t}=\left(\frac{1}{1-(1-\varepsilon)^{\frac{t}{n-1}}}\right)^{\alpha-1}$, then the inequality (2.6) can be written as

$$
\exp \left(\alpha(1-\varepsilon) L\left|k_{j}\right|^{1 / \alpha}\right) \leq h(\varepsilon, \alpha) \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{L^{n \alpha}}{n!^{\alpha}}\left|k_{j}\right|^{\alpha}
$$

Thus, we can obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\hat{f}(k)| & \leq \frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\|f\|_{\alpha, L} \frac{1}{\sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \frac{L^{|\beta| \alpha}}{\beta!^{\alpha}}} \\
& =\frac{1}{(2 \pi)^{d}}\|f\|_{\alpha, L} \frac{1}{\prod_{j=1}^{d} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{L^{n \alpha}}{n!^{\alpha}}\left|k_{j}\right|^{n}} \\
& \leq\left(\frac{h(\varepsilon, \alpha)}{2 \pi}\right)^{d}\|f\|_{\alpha, L} \exp \left(-\alpha(1-\varepsilon) L \sum_{j=1}^{d}\left|k_{j}\right|^{1 / \alpha}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Proposition 2.4 tells us that the $k$-Fourier coefficients of Gevrey functions exhibit subexponential decay with rate $\alpha(L-\varepsilon)|k|_{\alpha}$, corresponding to the Gevrey width. On the other hand, if the Fourier coefficients of a function $f$ exhibit sub-exponential decay, then $f$ is Gevrey function. In the following, we provide a precise description.

We first consider the Gevrey norm of $e^{i k \cdot x}$.
Lemma 2.5. Let $\alpha>1$ and $L>0$, then we have

$$
\left\|e^{i k \cdot x}\right\|_{\alpha, L} \leq e^{\alpha L|k|_{\alpha}}
$$

Proof. By the definition of $\|\cdot\|_{\alpha, L}$, we have

$$
\left\|e^{i k \cdot x}\right\|_{\alpha, L}=\sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \frac{L^{|\beta| / \alpha}}{\beta!^{\alpha}} \prod_{j=1}^{d}\left|k_{j}\right|^{\beta_{j}}=\sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \prod_{j=1}^{d}\left|k_{j}\right|^{\beta_{j}} \frac{L^{\beta_{j} \alpha}}{\beta_{j}!^{\alpha}}
$$

This simplifies to

$$
\begin{aligned}
\sum_{\beta \in \mathbb{N}^{d}} \prod_{j=1}^{d}\left|k_{j}\right|^{\beta_{j}} \frac{L^{\beta_{j} \alpha}}{\beta_{j}!^{\alpha}} & =\prod_{j=1}^{d} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty}\left(\frac{\left|k_{j}\right|^{n / \alpha}}{n!} L^{n}\right)^{\alpha} \\
& \leq\left(\prod_{j=1}^{d} \sum_{n=0}^{\infty} \frac{\left|k_{j}\right|^{n / \alpha}}{n!} L^{n}\right)^{\alpha} \\
& =\exp \left(\alpha L \sum_{j=1}^{d}\left|k_{j}\right|^{1 / \alpha}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

Therefore, we can naturally define a norm for $f$ defined on $\mathbb{T}^{d}$ as follows:

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L}}:=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}} e^{\alpha L|k|_{\alpha}}|\hat{f}(k)|
$$

We denote by $\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L}$ the set of smooth functions $f \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{T}^{d}\right)$ such that $\|f\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L}}<\infty$. The two norms we have defined are related as follows:

Proposition 2.6. Let $f \in C^{\infty}\left(\mathbb{T}^{d}\right)$. Then:
(1) $\|f\|_{\alpha, L} \leq\|f\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L}}$.
(2) $\|f\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha,(1-\varepsilon) L-\delta}} \leq\left(\frac{h(\varepsilon, \alpha)}{2 \pi}\right)^{d} C_{\delta}\|f\|_{\alpha, L}$, where $C_{\delta}=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}} e^{-\alpha \delta|k|_{\alpha}} \lesssim(\alpha \delta)^{-\alpha}$, and $h(\varepsilon, \alpha)$ is as defined above.

Proof. Part (1) is straightforward by Lemma 2.5. For part (2), we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|f\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha,(1-\varepsilon) L-\delta}} & =\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}} \exp \left(\alpha((1-\varepsilon) L-\delta)|k|_{\alpha}\right)|\hat{f}(k)| \\
& \leq\left(\frac{h(\varepsilon, \alpha)}{2 \pi}\right)^{d}\|f\|_{\alpha, L} \sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}} e^{-\alpha \delta|k|_{\alpha}} \\
& =\left(\frac{h(\varepsilon, \alpha)}{2 \pi}\right)^{d} C_{\delta}\|f\|_{\alpha, L}
\end{aligned}
$$

We can express part (2) of Proposition 2.6 in a more concise form as follows:
Corollary 2.7. There exists a constant $C_{\alpha, d}$ that depends only on $\alpha$ and $d$ such that

$$
\|f\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha,(1-\varepsilon) L-\delta}} \leq C_{\alpha, d} \varepsilon^{-(\alpha-1) d} \delta^{-\alpha d}\|f\|_{\alpha, L}
$$

Proof. It suffices to notice that

$$
\begin{aligned}
h(\varepsilon, \alpha) & =\left(\frac{1}{1-(1-\epsilon)^{\frac{1}{\alpha-1}}}\right)^{\alpha-1} \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{1-\left(1-\frac{\alpha}{\alpha-1} \varepsilon+O\left(\varepsilon^{2}\right)\right)}\right)^{\alpha-1} \\
& =\left(\frac{1}{\frac{\alpha}{\alpha-1} \varepsilon+O\left(\varepsilon^{2}\right)}\right)^{\alpha-1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Next, we discuss truncation techniques in Gevrey space.
Definition 2.8. Let $I \subset \mathbb{N}^{n}$ be a closed interval, and let $\lambda_{0} \in I$. Let $V$ be a Banach algebra with norm denoted by $\left\|\cdot\right\|_{V}$, and let $\varphi: I \rightarrow V$ be a $V$-valued map. We say that $\varphi$ admits a Gevrey- $(\alpha, L)$ asymptotic expansion at $\lambda_{0}$ if there exists a formal series

$$
\widetilde{\varphi}(\lambda)=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{N}^{n}}\left(\lambda-\lambda_{0}\right)^{k} \varphi_{k}
$$

where $\varphi_{k} \in V$ for each $k \in \mathbb{N}^{n}$, and a constant $C$ such that, for all $\lambda \in I$ and for all $p>0$,

$$
\left\|\varphi(\lambda)-\sum_{|k|<p}\left(\lambda-\lambda_{0}\right)^{k} \varphi_{k}\right\|_{V} \leq C p!^{\alpha-1} L^{-p \alpha}\left|\lambda-\lambda_{0}\right|_{1}^{p}
$$

This definition differs slightly from the traditional definition of Gevrey asymptotic expansions, as it involves multiple variables. In fact, this can be viewed as a definition of a Gevrey-type $V$-valued function. For a more usual framework of Gevrey asymptotic expansions, the reader is referred to [Bal94],[RS96], and [Tou90].

Lemma 2.9. Let $K_{1} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ be a closed interval, and let $K_{2}$ be an m-dimensional compact set. Let $\alpha>1$ and $L_{1}, L_{2}>0$. If $\varphi(\lambda, x) \in G^{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}\left(K_{1} \times K_{2}\right)$, then we have

$$
\forall k_{1} \in \mathbb{N}^{n}, \quad \sup _{\lambda \in K_{1}}\left\|\partial_{\lambda}^{k_{1}} \varphi(\lambda, \cdot)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} \leq\left(\frac{k_{1}!}{L_{1}^{\left|k_{1}\right|_{1}}}\right)^{\alpha}\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}
$$

Proof. Fix $\lambda \in K_{1}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\partial_{\lambda}^{k_{1}} \varphi(\lambda, \cdot)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} & =\sum_{k_{2} \in \mathbb{N}^{m}}\left(\frac{L_{2}^{\left|k_{2}\right|_{1}}}{k_{2}!}\right)^{\alpha}\left\|\partial_{x}^{k_{2}} \partial_{\lambda}^{k_{1}} \varphi\right\|_{C^{0}\left(K_{2}\right)} \\
& =\left(\frac{k_{1}!}{L_{1}^{\left|k_{1}\right|_{1}}}\right)^{\alpha} \sum_{k_{2} \in \mathbb{N}^{m}}\left(\frac{L_{1}^{\left|k_{1}\right|_{1}} L_{2}^{\left|k_{2}\right|_{1}}}{k_{1}!k_{2}!}\right)^{\alpha}\left\|\partial_{\lambda}^{k_{1}} \partial_{x}^{k_{2}} \varphi\right\|_{C^{0}\left(K_{2}\right)} \\
& \leq\left(\frac{k_{1}!}{L_{1}^{\left|k_{1}\right|_{1}}}\right)^{\alpha}\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Proposition 2.10. Let $K=K_{1} \times K_{2}$, where $K_{1} \subset \mathbb{R}^{n}$ is a closed interval, and $K_{2}$ is an $m$-dimensional compact set. Let $\lambda_{0} \in K_{1}$. For any $\varphi(\lambda, x) \in G^{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}(K)$, we can regard $\varphi$ as a map from $K_{1}$ to $G^{\alpha, L_{2}}\left(K_{2}\right)$, and the Taylor series

$$
\widetilde{\varphi}\left(\lambda_{0}+\Delta \lambda, x\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{\infty} \frac{1}{k!}\left(\Delta \lambda_{1} \partial_{\lambda_{1}}+\cdots+\Delta \lambda_{n} \partial_{\lambda_{n}}\right)^{k} \varphi\left(\lambda_{0}, x\right)
$$

is the Gevrey- $\left(\alpha, L_{2}\right)$ asymptotic expansion of $\varphi$ at $\lambda_{0}$.
Proof. Denote

$$
\widetilde{\varphi}_{p}\left(\lambda_{0}+\Delta \lambda, x\right)=\sum_{k=0}^{p} \frac{1}{k!}\left(\Delta \lambda_{1} \partial_{\lambda_{1}}+\cdots+\Delta \lambda_{n} \partial_{\lambda_{n}}\right)^{k} \varphi\left(\lambda_{0}, x\right)
$$

By Taylor's formula, we have

$$
\varphi(\lambda, x)-\widetilde{\varphi}_{p}(\lambda, x)=\frac{1}{p!} \int_{0}^{1}(1-t)^{p}\left(\Delta \lambda_{1} \partial_{\lambda_{1}}+\cdots+\Delta \lambda_{n} \partial_{\lambda_{n}}\right)^{p+1} \varphi\left(\lambda_{0}+t \Delta \lambda, x\right) d t
$$

where $\lambda=\lambda_{0}+\Delta \lambda$. Thus, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \|\varphi(\lambda, x)-\widetilde{\varphi}_{p}(\lambda, x)\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} \\
\leq & \frac{1}{p!} \int_{0}^{1}|(1-t)|^{p}\left\|\left(\Delta \lambda_{1} \partial_{\lambda_{1}}+\cdots+\Delta \lambda_{n} \partial_{\lambda_{n}}\right)^{p+1} \varphi\left(\lambda_{0}+t \Delta \lambda\right)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} d t \\
\leq & \frac{1}{p!} \int_{0}^{1}|(1-t)|^{p}\left\|\sum_{\substack{\lambda \in \mathbb{N}^{n} \\
|k|=p+1}} \frac{(p+1)!}{k!} \Delta \lambda^{k} \partial_{\lambda}^{k} \varphi\left(\lambda_{0}+t \Delta \lambda, x\right)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} d t \\
\leq & \frac{1}{p!} \int_{0}^{1}(1-t)^{p} d t \sum_{\substack{\lambda \in \mathbb{N}^{n} \\
|k|=p+1}} \frac{(p+1)!}{k!}\left|\Delta \lambda^{k}\right| \sup _{0 \leq t \leq 1}\left\|\partial_{\lambda}^{k} \varphi\left(\lambda_{0}+t \Delta \lambda, x\right)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Using Lemma 2.9, we have

$$
\left\|\partial_{\lambda}^{k} \varphi\left(\lambda_{0}+t \Delta \lambda, x\right)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} \leq\left(\frac{k!}{L_{1}^{\left|k\right|_{1}}}\right)^{\alpha}\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}
$$

Thus, we obtain

$$
\|\varphi(\lambda, x)-\widetilde{\varphi}_{p}(\lambda, x)\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} \leq \frac{1}{p!} \int_{0}^{1}(1-t)^{p} d t \sum_{\substack{\lambda \in \mathbb{N}^{n} \\
|k|_{1}=p+1}} \frac{(p+1)!}{k!}\left|\Delta \lambda^{k}\right|\left(\frac{k!}{L_{1}^{\left|k\right|_{1}}}\right)^{\alpha}\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}
$$

This simplifies to

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left\|\varphi(\lambda, x)-\widehat{\varphi}_{p}(\lambda, x)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} \\
\leqslant & \frac{1}{(p+1)!} \frac{\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}}{L_{1}^{(p+1) \alpha}} \sum_{\substack{k \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \\
|k|_{1}=p+1}} \frac{(p+1)!}{k!}\left|\Delta \lambda^{k}\right| \cdot k!^{\alpha} \\
\leqslant & \frac{(p+1)!^{\alpha-1}}{L_{1}^{(p+1) \alpha}}\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}} \sum_{\substack{k \in \mathbb{R}^{n} \\
|k|_{1}=p+1}} \frac{(p+1)!}{k!}\left|\Delta \lambda^{k}\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Finally, using the multi-dimensional binomial formula, we conclude that

$$
\left\|\varphi(\lambda, x)-\widehat{\varphi}_{p}(\lambda, x)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{2}} \leq\|\varphi\|_{\alpha, L_{1}, L_{2}}(p+1)!^{\alpha-1} L_{1}^{-(p+1) \alpha}|\Delta \lambda|_{1}^{p+1}
$$

Thus, the proof is complete.
We now present a frequently used lemma.
Lemma 2.11. Let $F$ be a Gevrey function, and suppose its derivative $F^{\prime} \in G^{\alpha, L}([-1,1])$. Let $q$ and $\Delta q$ be functions defined on $K$, and assume $q+t \Delta q \in G^{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}(K)$ for all $t \in[0,1]$, where $L, \boldsymbol{L}>0$ and $K$ is an m-dimensional compact set. If $\|q+t \Delta q\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}} \leq \frac{L^{n}}{m^{n-1}}$ for all $t \in[0,1]$, $\|q\|_{C^{0}(K)} \ll 1,\|\Delta q\|_{C^{0}(K)} \ll 1$, and $\|q+\Delta q\|_{C^{0}(K)} \ll 1$, then we have

$$
\|F(q+\Delta q)-F(q)\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}} \leq\left\|F^{\prime}\right\|_{\alpha, L}\|\Delta q\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}
$$

Proof. Observe that

$$
F(q+\Delta q)-F(q)=\int_{0}^{1} F^{\prime}(q+t \Delta q) \cdot \Delta q d t
$$

Thus, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|F(q+\Delta q)-F(q)\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}} & =\left\|\int_{0}^{1} F^{\prime}(q+t \Delta q) \cdot \Delta q d t\right\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}} \\
& \leq \int_{0}^{1}\left\|F^{\prime}(q+t \Delta q)\right\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}\|\Delta q\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}} d t \\
& \leq\left\|F^{\prime}\right\|_{\alpha, L^{\prime}}\|\Delta q\|_{\alpha, \boldsymbol{L}}
\end{aligned}
$$

# 3 Lyapounov-Schmidt decomposition 

In this section, we describe the Lyapunov-Schmidt decomposition. We begin by defining quasiperiodic functions, along with their associated frequencies and hulls.

Definition 3.1. A function $\tilde{q}(t, \tilde{x})$ is called quasi-periodic in time $t$ if there exist $\lambda \in \mathbb{R}^{b}$ and $q(\theta, \tilde{x}) \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{T}^{b+d}\right)$, with $\theta \in \mathbb{T}^{b}$ and $\tilde{x} \in \mathbb{T}^{d}$, such that

$$
\tilde{q}(t, \tilde{x})=q(\lambda t, \tilde{x})
$$

Here, $\lambda$ is referred to as the frequency, and $q(\theta, \tilde{x})$ as the hull of $\tilde{q}(t, \tilde{x})$. When it is expressed as a Fourier series, we obtain

$$
\tilde{q}(t, \tilde{x})=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^{b}, n \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}} \tilde{q}(k, n) e^{i \lambda \cdot k t+i n \cdot \tilde{x}}
$$

where $\tilde{q}(k, n)$ denotes the Fourier coefficients of $q(\theta, \tilde{x})$.

To find quasi-periodic solutions with frequency $\lambda^{\prime}$ to equation (1.1) is equivalent to solve

$$
\frac{1}{i} \lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta} q-\mathcal{L} q-\varepsilon \frac{\partial H}{\partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})=0
$$

where $\lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta}:=\sum_{j=1}^{b} \lambda_{j}^{\prime} \partial_{\theta_{j}}$. Taking the conjugate of (3.3), we obtain

$$
-\frac{1}{i} \lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta} \bar{q}-\mathcal{L}^{\prime} \bar{q}-\varepsilon \frac{\partial H}{\partial q}(q, \bar{q})=0
$$

where $\mathcal{L}^{\prime}$ is the operator with the multiplier $\left\{\mu_{n}^{\prime}=\mu_{-n}\right\}_{n \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}}$.
The lattice formulation of (3.3) is as follows:

$$
\left(k \cdot \lambda^{\prime}-\mu_{n}\right) \hat{q}(n, k)-\varepsilon \frac{\widehat{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})(n, k)=0, \quad\left(n \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}, k \in \mathbb{Z}^{b}\right)
$$

where $\frac{\widehat{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})(n, k)$ represents the $(n, k)$-Fourier coefficient of $\frac{\partial H}{\partial q}(q, \bar{q})$. If we can find $\lambda^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}^{b}$ and a sequence $\{\hat{q}(n, k)\}_{n \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}, k \in \mathbb{Z}^{b}}$ with a certain degree of decay that satisfies (3.5), then the function

$$
\hat{q}(t, \tilde{x})=\sum_{k \in \mathbb{Z}^{b}, n \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}} \hat{q}(k, n) e^{i \lambda^{\prime} \cdot k t+i n \cdot \tilde{x}}
$$

with the found $\lambda^{\prime}$ and $\hat{q}(n, k)$ is a quasi-periodic solution to equation (1.1) with the corresponding regularity. Denote by $\|\cdot\|$ the norm of $L^{2}\left({ }_{x}^{a_{0}+d}\right)$. If there exists $q(\theta, \tilde{x}) \in L^{2}\left({ }_{x}^{a_{0}+d}\right)$ such that

$$
\left\|\frac{1}{i} \lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta} q-\mathcal{L} q-\varepsilon \frac{\partial H}{\partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})\right\|<\delta
$$

for $\lambda^{\prime} \in \mathbb{R}^{b}$, then the quasi-periodic function $\hat{q}(t, x)$, with the hull $q(\theta, \tilde{x})$ and frequency $\lambda^{\prime}$, is referred to as an $O(\delta)$ approximate solution to (1.1).

Let $\mathcal{R}=\left\{\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right) \mid 1 \leq j \leq b\right\}$, which we refer to as the resonant set. We specify the Fourier coefficients as

$$
\hat{q}\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)=a_{j}, \quad 1 \leq j \leq b
$$

To describe the Lyapounov-Schmidt decomposition, we introduce the following definition.
Definition 3.2. Let $g(\theta, \tilde{x}) \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{T}^{b+d}\right)$. We define the projection operators $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{Q}, \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P}$ and $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}}$ as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{Q} g=\sum_{(n, k) \in \mathcal{R}} \hat{g}(n, k) e^{i n \cdot \tilde{x}+i k \cdot \theta} \\
& \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} g=\sum_{(n, k) \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}} \hat{g}(n, k) e^{i n \cdot \tilde{x}+i k \cdot \theta} \\
& \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} g=\sum_{(n, k) \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash(-\mathcal{R})} \hat{g}(n, k) e^{i n \cdot \tilde{x}+i k \cdot \theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

Denote the left side of (3.3) by $F(q)$, i.e.,

$$
F(q)=\frac{1}{i} \lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta} q-\mathcal{L} q-\varepsilon \frac{\partial H}{\partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})
$$

then (3.3) is equivalent to

$$
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{Q} F(q)=0
$$

$$
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q)=0
$$

Passing equations (3.10) and (3.11) to Fourier coefficients, we obtain the following lattice equations:

$$
\begin{gathered}
\left(\lambda_{j}^{\prime}-\lambda_{j}\right) a_{j}-\varepsilon \frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial \hat{q}}(q, \hat{q})\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)=0, \quad 1 \leq j \leq b \\
\left(k \cdot \lambda^{\prime}-\mu_{n}\right) \hat{q}(n, k)-\varepsilon \frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial \hat{q}}(q, \hat{q})(n, k)=0, \quad(n, k) \notin \mathcal{R}
\end{gathered}
$$

we refer to the finite equations (3.12) as the Q-equations and the infinite equations (3.13) as the $\mathbf{P}$-equations.

However, the P-equations cannot be addressed using a standard implicit function theorem due to the presence of small divisors. Consequently, we will solve P-equations using Newton's algorithm. To apply Newton's algorithm, it is necessary to duplicate equations (3.13). Note that $\hat{q}(-n,-k)=\hat{q}(n, k)$. Taking the conjugate of equations (3.13), we can duplicate them as follows:

$$
\begin{cases}\left(k \cdot \lambda^{\prime}-\mu_{n}\right) \hat{q}(n, k)-\varepsilon \frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial \hat{q}}(q, \hat{q})(n, k)=0 & (n, k) \notin \mathcal{R} \\ \left(-k \cdot \lambda^{\prime}-\mu_{-n}\right) \hat{q}(n, k)-\varepsilon \frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial q}(q, \hat{q})(n, k)=0 & (n, k) \notin-\mathcal{R}\end{cases}
$$

We will see that the relation $\hat{q}(-n,-k)=\hat{q}(n, k)$ is preserved for the approximate solutions in Newton's algorithm. In fact, the second equality in (3.14) is simply $\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} \bar{F}(q)=0$ modulo a Fourier transform. Therefore, up to a Fourier transform, (3.14) can be written as follows:

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q)=0 \\
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} \bar{F}(q)=0
\end{array}\right.
$$

We also refer to both (3.14) and (3.15) as the $P$-equations.
Thus, the general procedure is to determine $\hat{q}(n, k) \|_{(n, k) \notin \mathcal{R}}$ (which depends on $\lambda^{\prime}$ and $\lambda$ ) from the $P$-equations, and then substitute it into $Q$-equations to obtain the new frequencies $\lambda^{\prime}=\left(\lambda_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, \lambda_{b}^{\prime}\right)$. Note that the frequencies $\lambda_{1}^{\prime}, \ldots, \lambda_{b}^{\prime}$ need to be real, otherwise the function (3.6) cannot represent a quasi-periodic solution to (1.1). We will demonstrate the reality of $\lambda^{\prime}$ through our construction by applying Proposition A. 1 in the Appendix.

# 4 The homological equations and the estimate of the remians 

Now we describe the Newton iteration scheme to solve $P$-equations. Recall that $H(q, \hat{q})=f(q \hat{q})$. Let $q \in L^{2}\left({ }_{+}^{m b+d}\right), \Delta q \in L^{2}\left({ }_{+}^{m b+d}\right)$ and $\operatorname{supp} \overline{\Delta q} \subset \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}$, then we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
F(q+\Delta q)= & F(q)+\frac{1}{i} \lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta} \Delta q-\mathcal{L} \Delta q-\varepsilon \frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \hat{q}}(q, \hat{q}) \Delta q-\varepsilon \frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial \hat{q}^{2}}(q, \hat{q}) \overline{\Delta q} \\
& -\varepsilon \int_{0}^{1}(1-s)\left(\Delta q \frac{\partial}{\partial q}+\overline{\Delta q} \frac{\partial}{\partial \hat{q}}\right)^{2} \frac{\partial H}{\partial \hat{q}}(q+s \Delta q, \hat{q}+s \overline{\Delta q}) d s
\end{aligned}
$$

Taking the conjugate on both sides of (4.1), we have

$$
\begin{gathered}
\bar{F}(q+\Delta q)=\bar{F}(q)-\frac{1}{i} \lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta} \overline{\Delta q}-\mathcal{L}^{\prime} \overline{\Delta q}-\varepsilon \frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q^{2}}(q, \hat{q}) \Delta q-\varepsilon \frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \hat{q}}(q, \hat{q}) \overline{\Delta q} \\
-\varepsilon \int_{0}^{1}(1-s)\left(\Delta q \frac{\partial}{\partial q}+\overline{\Delta q} \frac{\partial}{\partial \hat{q}}\right)^{2} \frac{\partial H}{\partial q}(q+s \Delta q, \hat{q}+s \overline{\Delta q}) d s
\end{gathered}
$$

Summarizing equations (4.1) and (4.2), we conclude that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\binom{F(q+\Delta q)}{F(q+\Delta q)}= & \binom{F(q)}{F(q)}+\widetilde{T_{q}}\binom{\Delta q}{\Delta \bar{q}} \\
& +\binom{-\varepsilon \int_{0}^{1}(1-s)\left(\Delta q \frac{\partial}{\partial q}+\overline{\Delta q} \frac{\partial}{\partial q}\right)^{2} \frac{\partial H}{\partial \bar{q}}(q+s \Delta q, \bar{q}+s \overline{\Delta q}) d s}{-\varepsilon \int_{0}^{1}(1-s)\left(\Delta q \frac{\partial}{\partial q}+\overline{\Delta q} \frac{\partial}{\partial q}\right)^{2} \frac{\partial H}{\partial q}(q+s \Delta q, \bar{q}+s \overline{\Delta q}) d s}
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
\widetilde{T}_{q}=\left[\begin{array}{cc}
\binom{\frac{1}{i} \lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta}-\mathcal{L}}{0} & 0 \\
0 & -\frac{1}{i} \lambda^{\prime} \cdot \partial_{\theta}-\mathcal{L}^{\prime}
\end{array}\right)-\varepsilon\binom{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})}{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q^{2}}(q, \bar{q})} \quad \frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial \bar{q}^{2}}(q, \bar{q})}\binom{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})}{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}}(q, \bar{q})}
$$

Let

$$
\widetilde{T}_{q, P}\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta \bar{q}}\right)=-\binom{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q)}{\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} F(q)}
$$

where

$$
\widetilde{T}_{q, P}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} & 0 \\
0 & \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}}
\end{array}\right) \widetilde{T}_{q}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} & 0 \\
0 & \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}}
\end{array}\right)
$$

We denote $T_{q}=D-\varepsilon S_{q}$, where

$$
D=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
k \cdot \lambda^{\prime}-\mu_{n} & 0 \\
0 & -k \cdot \lambda^{\prime}-\mu_{-n}
\end{array}\right), \quad S_{q}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
S_{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})} & S_{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q^{2}}(q, \bar{q})} \\
\frac{S_{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q^{2}}(q, \bar{q})}}{\partial q^{2}} & S_{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and $S_{\phi}$ represents the Toeplitz operator corresponding to $\phi$-multiplication. The matrix index is $( \pm, n, k)$, where $n \in \mathbb{Z}^{d}, k \in \mathbb{Z}^{b}$, and the index of $\binom{\widehat{\Delta q}}{\widehat{\Delta q}}$ is also $( \pm, n, k)$. More precisely, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& S_{q}\left((+, n, k),\left(+, n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}\right)\right)=S_{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})}\left((n, k),\left(n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& S_{q}\left((+, n, k),\left(-, n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}\right)\right)=S_{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q^{2}}(q, \bar{q})}\left((n, k),\left(n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& S_{q}\left((-, n, k),\left(+, n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}\right)\right)=S_{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q^{2}}(q, \bar{q})}\left((n, k),\left(n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& S_{q}\left((-, n, k),\left(-, n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}\right)\right)=S_{\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})}\left((n, k),\left(n^{\prime}, k^{\prime}\right)\right) \\
& \left(\frac{\widehat{\Delta q}}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)(+, n, k)=\widehat{\Delta q}(n, k)
\end{aligned}
$$

and

$$
\binom{\widehat{\Delta q}}{\widehat{\Delta q}}(-, n, k)=\widehat{\widehat{\Delta q}}(n, k)
$$

Passing equation (4.5) to Fourier coefficients, we obtain the homological equation of (3.14):

$$
T_{q, P}\left(\frac{\widehat{\Delta q}}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)=-\binom{R_{P} \widehat{F(q)}}{R_{P^{\prime}} \widehat{F}(q)}
$$

where the linearized operator is given by

$$
T_{q, P}=R_{P \cup P^{\prime}}\left(D-\varepsilon S_{q}\right) R_{P \cup P^{\prime}}
$$

and $R_{P}$ refers to coordinate restriction to $\left(\mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}\right) \subset \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}, R_{P^{\prime}}$ refers to coordinate restriction to $\left(\mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash(-\mathcal{R})\right) \subset \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}$ and $R_{P \cup P^{\prime}}$ refers to coordinate restriction to $\{(+, n, k) \mid(n, k) \notin \mathcal{R}\} \cup$ $\{(-, n, k) \mid(n, k) \notin-\mathcal{R}\}$.

However, we cannot solve (4.8) directly. Instead, we aim to solve an approximation of (4.8) as follows:

$$
T_{q, P, N}\left(\frac{\widehat{\Delta q}}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)=\binom{-R_{P, N} \widehat{F(q)}}{-R_{P^{\prime}, N} \widehat{F(q)}}
$$

i.e.,

$$
\left(\frac{\widehat{\Delta q}}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)=\left(T_{q, P, N}\right)^{-1}\binom{-R_{P, N} \widehat{F(q)}}{-R_{P^{\prime}, N} \widehat{F(q)}}
$$

where $T_{q, P, N}=R_{P \cup P^{\prime}, N} T_{q} R_{P \cup P^{\prime}, N}$, and $R_{P, N}$ refers to coordinate restriction to

$$
\left(\left(\mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}\right) \cap\{|n|<N,|k|<N\}\right) \subset \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}
$$

$R_{P^{\prime}, N}$ refers to coordinate restriction to

$$
\left(\left(\mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash(-\mathcal{R})\right) \cap\{|n|<N,|k|<N\}\right) \subset \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}
$$

and $R_{P \cup P^{\prime}, N}$ refers to coordinate restriction to

$$
(\{(+, n, k) \mid(n, k) \notin \mathcal{R}\} \cup\{(-, n, k) \mid(n, k) \notin-\mathcal{R}\}) \cap\{|n|<N,|k|<N\}
$$

The solution $\Delta q$ and $\overline{\Delta q}$ obtained by solving equations (4.10) are conjugates of each other as the relation $\widehat{\Delta q}(-n,-k)=\widehat{\Delta q(n, k)}$ holds. Up to a Fourier transform, equation (4.10) can be rewritten as:

$$
\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)=\binom{-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N} F(q)}{-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}, N} \hat{F}(q)}
$$

where

$$
\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}=\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N} & 0 \\
0 & \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}, N}
\end{array}\right) \widetilde{T}_{q}\left(\begin{array}{cc}
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N} & 0 \\
0 & \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}, N}
\end{array}\right)
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N} h(\theta, \hat{x})=\sum_{\substack{(n, k) \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash(-\mathcal{R}) \\
|n|<N,|k|<N}} \hat{h}(n, k) e^{i n \cdot \hat{x}+i k \cdot \theta} \\
& \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}, N} h(\theta, \hat{x})=\sum_{\substack{(n, k) \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash(-\mathcal{R}) \\
|n|<N,|k|<N}} \hat{h}(n, k) e^{i n \cdot \hat{x}+i k \cdot \theta}
\end{aligned}
$$

for $h \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{T}^{b+d}\right)$. For $\Delta q, \overline{\Delta q}$ satisfying (4.10) (i.e.,(4.12)) we have supp $\widehat{\Delta q} \subset\left(\mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}\right) \cap\{|n|<$ $N,|k|<N\}$ and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left(\begin{array}{l}
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q+\Delta q) \\
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} F(q+\Delta q)
\end{array}\right)= & \left(\begin{array}{l}
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q) \\
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} \hat{F}(q)
\end{array}\right)+\widetilde{T}_{q, P}\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)+O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right) \\
= & \left(\begin{array}{l}
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N} F(q) \\
\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}, N} \hat{F}(q)
\end{array}\right)+\binom{\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P}-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N}\right) F(q)}{\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}}-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}, N}\right) \hat{F}(q)} \\
& +\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)+\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)+O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right) \\
= & \left(\begin{array}{l}
\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P}-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N}\right) F(q) \\
\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}}-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}, N}\right) \hat{F}(q)
\end{array}\right)+\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\widehat{\Delta q}}\right)+O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right)
\end{aligned}
$$

where

$$
O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right):=\binom{-\varepsilon \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} \int_{0}^{1}(1-s)\left(\Delta q \frac{\partial}{\partial q}+\widehat{\Delta q \frac{\partial}{\partial q}}\right)^{2} \frac{\partial H}{\partial q}(q+s \Delta q, \bar{q}+s \widehat{\Delta q}) d s}{-\varepsilon \boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} \int_{0}^{1}(1-s)\left(\Delta q \frac{\partial}{\partial q}+\widehat{\Delta q \frac{\partial}{\partial q}}\right)^{2} \frac{\partial H}{\partial q}(q+s \Delta q, \bar{q}+s \widehat{\Delta q}) d s}
$$

and we denote the first and the second components of $O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right)$ by $O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right)_{1}$ and $O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right)_{2}$ respectively. Assume one succeeds in ensuring that

$$
\left|T_{q, P, N}^{-1}\left((\nu, x),\left(\nu^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)\right)\right|<B(r) e^{-\alpha L^{(1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}
$$

where $\nu, \nu^{\prime}= \pm, x, x^{\prime} \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}, B(r)$ and $N$ is to be specified, and

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(0)}}}<\epsilon \\
\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} \bar{F}(q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(0)}}}<\epsilon \\
\|q\|_{\alpha, L^{(0)}} \ll 1
\end{array}\right.
$$

where $\epsilon$ is small, $L^{(0)}, L^{(1)}>0$ and $L^{(0)}>L^{(1)}$.
First, we estimate $\Delta q$. According to equation (4.11), for any $x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}$ and $|x|<N$, we have

$$
\widehat{\Delta q}(x)=\sum_{\substack{|y|<N \\ y \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}}} T_{q, P, N}^{-1}((+, x),(+, y)) \widehat{F(q)}(y)+\sum_{\substack{|y|<N \\ y \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash-\mathcal{R}}} T_{q, P, N}^{-1}((+, x),(-, y)) \widehat{F(q)}(y)
$$

Since $\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(0)}}}<\epsilon$ and $\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} \bar{F}(q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(0)}}}<\epsilon$, we have

$$
|\widehat{F(q)}(x)|<\epsilon e^{-\alpha L^{(0)}|x|_{\alpha}}, \text { for } x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}
$$

and

$$
|\widehat{F(q)}(x)|<\epsilon e^{-\alpha L^{(0)}|x|_{\alpha}}, \text { for } x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash-\mathcal{R}
$$

Thus,

$$
\begin{aligned}
|\widehat{\Delta q}(x)| \leq & \sum_{\substack{|y|<N \\
y \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}}}\left|T_{q, P, N}^{-1}((+, x),(+, y)) \| \widehat{F(q)}(y)\right| \\
& +\sum_{\substack{|y|<N \\
y \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash-\mathcal{R}}}\left|T_{q, P, N}^{-1}((+, x),(-, y)) \| \widehat{F(q)}(y)\right| \\
\leq & \sum_{\substack{|y|<N \\
y \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}}} \epsilon B(r) e^{-\alpha L^{(1)}|x-y|_{\alpha}} e^{-\alpha L^{(0)}|y|_{\alpha}}+\sum_{\substack{|y|<N \\
y \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash-\mathcal{R}}} \epsilon B(r) e^{-\alpha L^{(1)}|x-y|_{\alpha}} e^{-\alpha L^{(0)}|y|_{\alpha}} \\
& \leq \epsilon B(r) C_{\alpha} \delta^{-\alpha(b+d)} e^{-L^{(2)}|x|_{\alpha}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $0<\delta<L^{(1)}, L^{(2)}=L^{(1)}-\delta$ and $C_{\alpha}=\alpha^{-\alpha(b+d)}\left(\int_{0}^{+\infty} e^{-x^{1 / \alpha}} d x\right)^{b+d}$.
In the following part of this section, we make the following assumptions:

- $\epsilon=\varepsilon^{a^{\prime}}$ for some $1<a<2$,
- $\log B(r)<C r^{C} \log \log \frac{1}{\varepsilon}$,
- $\delta \sim r^{-C}$.

Based on these assumptions, we derive that

$$
|\widetilde{\Delta q}(x)| \leq \epsilon^{1-} e^{-\alpha L^{(2)}|x|_{\alpha}} \text { for } x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R}
$$

Additionally, the norm $\|\Delta q\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(2)}-\delta}}$ can be bounded as follows:

$$
\begin{aligned}
\|\Delta q\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(2)}-\delta}} & =\sum_{x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}}|\widetilde{\Delta q}(x)| \cdot e^{\alpha\left(L^{(2)}-\delta\right)|x|_{\alpha}} \\
& \leq \epsilon^{1-} \sum_{x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}} e^{-\alpha \delta|x|_{\alpha}} \\
& \leq \epsilon^{1-} C_{\alpha} \delta^{-\alpha(b+d)} \\
& \leq \epsilon^{1-}
\end{aligned}
$$

Now we estimate the three terms in (4.14).
Firstly, we consider $O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right)$. Let $L^{(3)}=L^{(2)}-\delta$, then $\|\Delta q\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(3)}} \leq \epsilon^{1-}}$. Therefore, we have

$$
\left\|O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right)_{1}\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(3)}}<\epsilon^{2-}} \text { and }\left\|O\left(\Delta q^{2}\right)_{2}\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(3)}}<\epsilon^{2-}}
$$

where $L^{(4)}=L^{(3)}-\delta$.
Recalling the definition of $T_{q}$, we get

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left|T_{q}\left((\nu, x),\left(\nu^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)\right)\right|<\varepsilon, \quad \nu, \nu^{\prime}= \pm, x \neq x^{\prime},\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|<\delta^{-C} \\
\left|T_{q}\left((\nu, x),\left(\nu^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)\right)\right|<e^{-\alpha\left(L^{(0)}-\delta\right)\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}, \quad\left|x-x^{\prime}\right| \geq \delta^{-C}
\end{array}\right.
$$

since $\|q\|_{\alpha, L^{(0)}} \ll 1$.
Secondly, we consider the term:

$$
\binom{\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P}-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N}\right) F(q)}{\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}}-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}, N}\right) F(q)}
$$

Taking $\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P}-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N}\right) F(q)$ for example, since $\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(0)}}}<\epsilon$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left\|\left(\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P}-\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P, N}\right) F(q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(2)}}} & =\sum_{|x| \geq N, x \notin \mathcal{R}}|\widehat{F(q)}(x)| e^{\alpha L^{(2)}|x|_{\alpha}} \\
& \leq \sum_{|x| \geq N, x \notin \mathcal{R}} \epsilon e^{-\alpha L^{(0)}|x|_{\alpha}+\alpha L^{(2)}|x|_{\alpha}} \\
& \leq \epsilon \sum_{|x| \geq N, x \notin \mathcal{R}} e^{-\alpha \delta|x|_{\alpha}} \\
& \lesssim \epsilon(\alpha \delta)^{-\alpha(b+d)} e^{-\frac{1}{2} \alpha \delta N^{1 / \alpha}}
\end{aligned}
$$

If we choose $N=A^{\alpha r}$ for large $A$ (for example $A=\left(\log \frac{1}{\epsilon}\right)^{\alpha}$ ), then $\epsilon r^{C} e^{-\frac{1}{2} r^{-C} A^{r}}<\epsilon^{2}$.
Thirdly, we consider

$$
\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta q}\right)
$$

For $\nu= \pm$ and $|x|<N$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta q}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(\nu, x) \\
= & \sum_{|y|<N}\left[T_{q, P}((\nu, x),(+, y))-T_{q, P, N}((\nu, x),(+, y))\right] \widetilde{\Delta q}(y)+ \\
& \sum_{|y|<N}\left[T_{q, P}((\nu, x),(-, y))-T_{q, P, N}((\nu, x),(-, y))\right] \widetilde{\Delta q}(y) \\
= & 0
\end{aligned}
$$

For $\nu= \pm$ and $|x| \geq N$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left(\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta q}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(\nu, x) \\
= & \sum_{|y|<N}\left|T_{q, P}((\nu, x),(+, y)) \widehat{\Delta q}(y)\right|+\sum_{|y|<N}\left|T_{q, P}((\nu, x),(-, y)) \widehat{\widehat{\Delta q}}(y)\right| \\
= & \sum_{|x-y|<\delta-C} N^{2}(|\widehat{\Delta q}(y)|+\widehat{|\widehat{\Delta q}(y)|})+\sum_{|x-y| \geq \delta-C} e^{-\alpha\left(L^{(0)}-\delta\right)|x-y|_{a}}(|\widehat{\Delta q}(y)|+\widehat{|\widehat{\Delta q}(y)|}) \\
\leq & \epsilon^{1-\left(\sum_{|x-y|<\delta-C} e^{-\alpha L^{(3)}|y|_{a}}+\sum_{|x-y| \geq \delta} e^{-\alpha L^{(3)}|x-y|_{a}} e^{-\alpha L^{(3)}|y|_{a}}\right)} \\
\leq & \epsilon^{1-\left(\delta-C} e^{\alpha L^{(3)} \delta-C} e^{-\alpha L^{(3)}|x|_{a}}+C_{\alpha} \delta^{-\alpha(b+d)} e^{-\alpha L^{(4)}|x|_{a}}\right)} \\
\leq & \epsilon^{1-\left.e^{-\alpha L^{(4)}|x|_{a}}\right.}
\end{aligned}
$$

Denote by

$$
\left(\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta q}\right)\right)_{1}
$$

and

$$
\left(\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta q}\right)\right)_{2}
$$

the first and the second components of $\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta q}\right)$ respectively. Let $L^{(5)}=L^{(4)}-\delta$, as discussion in (4.21). We then have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left\|\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta q}\right)\right)_{1}\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(5)}}} \leq \epsilon^{1-}(\alpha \delta)^{-\alpha(b+d)} e^{-\frac{1}{2} \alpha \delta N^{1 / \alpha}}<\epsilon^{2} \\
\left\|\left(\widetilde{T}_{q, P}-\widetilde{T}_{q, P, N}\right)\left(\frac{\Delta q}{\Delta q}\right)\right)_{2}\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(5)}} \leq \epsilon^{1-}(\alpha \delta)^{-\alpha(b+d)} e^{-\frac{1}{2} \alpha \delta N^{1 / \alpha}}<\epsilon^{2}}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Thus, we have $\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q+\Delta q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(5)}}<\epsilon^{2-}}$ and $\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} \bar{F}(q+\Delta q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(5)}}<\epsilon^{2-}}$.
Thus under the assumptions (4.16) and (4.17), we can find $\Delta q$ such that

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F(q+\Delta q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(5)}}}<\epsilon^{2-}<\varepsilon^{a^{\nu+1}} \\
\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} \bar{F}(q+\Delta q)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(5)}}}<\epsilon^{2-}<\varepsilon^{a^{\nu+1}} \\
\|q+\Delta q\|_{\alpha, L^{(3)}} \ll 1
\end{array}\right.
$$

Moreover, we have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\Delta q} \subset\left\{x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}||x|<N\right\} \cap \mathcal{R} \\
\|\Delta q\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L^{(3)}}<\epsilon^{1-}}
\end{array}\right.
$$

Thus our main task is to obtain (4.16) at each step, i.e., the estimate of the inverse of the linearized operator $T_{q, P, N}^{-1}$. In the sequel, we refer to $T_{q, P, N}^{-1}$ as the Green function.

Now we consider the Q-equations:

$$
\left(\lambda_{j}^{\prime}-\lambda_{j}\right) a_{j}-\varepsilon \frac{\partial \bar{\partial} \bar{\partial}}{\partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)=0, \quad 1 \leq j \leq b
$$

i.e.,

$$
\lambda_{j}^{\prime}=\lambda_{j}+\varepsilon \frac{1}{a_{j}} \frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)
$$

In fact, to maintain the bound of the Green function, some conditions on $\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}, a\right)$ need to be satisfied. However, we assume that $\left.\bar{q}\right|_{(n, k) \notin \mathcal{R}}$ are defined as $C^{1}$ functions over the entire $\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$ parameter space $I_{0} \times I_{0} \subset \mathbb{R}^{2 b}$ (we will extend q to the entire parameter space). Moreover, assume $\|\partial q\|_{C\left(I_{0} \times I_{0}\right)}<C$ (where $\partial$ refers to derivative with respect to $\lambda$ or $\lambda^{\prime}$ ), then we have $\left|\partial \frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)\right|<C$.

Let

$$
G\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)=\left(\lambda_{j}^{\prime}-\lambda_{j}-\varepsilon \frac{1}{a_{j}} \frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)\right)_{j=1, \ldots, b}
$$

then

$$
\frac{\partial G\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)}{\partial \lambda^{\prime}}=I d+O(\varepsilon)
$$

and

$$
\operatorname{det}\left(\frac{\partial G\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)}{\partial \lambda^{\prime}}\right) \neq 0 \text { for all }\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right) \in I_{0} \times I_{0}
$$

Thus, we can solve $\lambda^{\prime}$ from (4.27) to get a solution such that:

$$
\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda+\varepsilon \varphi(\lambda), \quad\|\varphi\|_{C^{1}\left(I_{0}\right)}<C
$$

If there are two functions $q^{(1)}, q^{(2)}$ satisfying

$$
\left\|q^{(1)}\right\|_{C^{1}\left(I_{0}\right)}<C, \quad\left\|q^{(2)}\right\|_{C^{1}\left(I_{0}\right)}<C
$$

and we denote their respective solutions as $\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda+\varepsilon \varphi^{(1)}(\lambda)$ and $\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda+\varepsilon \varphi^{(2)}(\lambda)$, then we have the following inequality:

$$
\left\|\varphi^{(1)}-\varphi^{(2)}\right\|_{C^{0}\left(I_{0}\right)} \lesssim\left\|q^{(1)}-q^{(2)}\right\|_{C^{0}\left(I_{0}\right)}
$$

# 5 The Iterative Lemma 

We define the following iterative constants and domains:

- $\alpha>1, L_{0}>0$ corresponding to the Gevrey function $f$.
- $r \geq 0$, the number of Newton iteration steps.
- $q_{r}\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)(\theta, \tilde{x}) \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{T}^{k+d}\right)$, the approximate solution at the $r$-th step.
- $q_{0}(\theta, \tilde{x})=\sum_{1 \leq j \leq b} a_{j} e^{i n_{j} \cdot \tilde{x}+i e_{j} \cdot \theta}$.
- $\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda+\varepsilon \varphi_{r}(\lambda)$ is the solution of

$$
\left(\lambda_{j}^{\prime}-\lambda_{j}\right) a_{j}-\varepsilon \frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}\left(q_{r}, \bar{q}_{r}\right)\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)=0, \quad 1 \leq j \leq b
$$

- $A=\left(\log \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)^{\alpha}, N_{r}=A^{r}$.

- $\epsilon_{r}=\varepsilon^{\left(\frac{4}{3}\right)^{r}}$.
- $\delta_{r}=\frac{3 L_{r}}{10 \pi^{2} r^{3}}$.
- $L_{r}=L_{0}-10 \sum_{j=1}^{r} \delta_{j}$, and for $1 \leq j \leq 10, L_{r}^{(j)}=L_{r-1}-j \delta_{r}, L_{r}^{(0, j)}=L_{r-1}-\frac{j \delta_{r}}{10}$.
- $B(0, N):=\left\{x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}:|x|<N\right\}$.
- $\Gamma_{r}$, the graph of $\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda+\varepsilon \varphi_{r}(\lambda)$.

Choose constants $C_{1}, C_{2}, C_{3}$ such that $C_{1}>C_{2}+2$ and $C_{2}>C_{3}>10$. We now state the following Iterative Lemma:
Lemma 5.1 (Iterative Lemma). Let $r \geq 1$, and for each step $r$, there exists an approximate solution $q_{r}\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)(\theta, \tilde{x}) \in L^{2}\left(\mathbb{T}^{b+d}\right)$ defined on $I_{0} \times I_{0} \subset \mathbb{R}^{2 b}$, and these solutions are $C^{1}$ with respect to $\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$. They satisfy the following statements:
(r.1) $\operatorname{supp} \hat{q}_{r} \mid \mathbb{Z}^{b+d} \backslash \mathcal{R} \subset B\left(0, N_{r}\right)$, and $\hat{q}_{r}(x) \in \mathbb{R}$ for $x \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}$.
(r.2) Let $\Delta q_{r}=q_{r}-q_{r-1}$. Then $\operatorname{supp} \widehat{\Delta q_{r}} \subset B\left(0, N_{r}\right) \backslash \mathcal{R}$ and $\left\|\Delta q_{r}\right\|_{C^{1}\left(I_{0} \times I_{0}\right)}<\epsilon_{r-1}^{1-}$.
(r.3) There exists a collection $\Lambda_{r}$ of intervals $I$ in $\mathbb{R}^{2 b}$ of size $A^{-\alpha(r+2)^{C_{1}}}$, such that:
(r.3.a) Let $T=T_{q_{r-1}}$. For $\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right) \in \bigcup_{I \in \Lambda_{r}} I$, we have

$$
\left|T_{P, \tilde{N}_{r}}^{-1}\left(\left(\nu, x\right),\left(\nu^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)\right)\right|<2 B(r) e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}} \text { for } \nu, \nu^{\prime}= \pm, x, x^{\prime} \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}
$$

where $B(r)=A^{r^{C_{3}}}$.
(r.3.b) Let $I \in \Lambda_{r}$. Then $q_{r}\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$ is given by a rational function of $\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$ of degree at most $A^{r^{3}}$ on $I$, and we have

$$
\left\{\begin{array}{l}
\left\|\Delta q_{r}\right\|_{\alpha, L_{r}}<\epsilon_{r-1}^{1-} \\
\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P} F\left(q_{r}\right)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L_{r}}} \lesssim \epsilon_{r} \\
\left\|\boldsymbol{\Gamma}_{P^{\prime}} \bar{F}\left(q_{r}\right)\right\|_{\mathcal{F}_{\alpha, L_{r}}} \lesssim \epsilon_{r}
\end{array}\right.

# 5.1 Estimate of the Green function in first finite steps 

As mentioned in the previous section, the key point is to obtain the bound for the Green function. Throughout the estimation of the Green function, one can easily observe that the index $\nu= \pm$ plays a minimal role in establishing the bound. Therefore, for simplicity, we omit the index $\nu= \pm$ and write $T\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)=T\left((\nu, x),\left(\nu^{\prime}, x^{\prime}\right)\right)$ in the sequel.
In this subsection, we will prove (r.3.d) for $r \leq C \log \log \frac{1}{r}(C>2 \alpha$ can be large).
Recall that $T_{q, P, N}=D_{P, N}-\varepsilon S_{q, P, N}$, and we have the following expressions:

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}(q, \bar{q})=f^{\prime \prime}\left(|q|^{2}\right)|q|^{2}+f^{\prime}\left(|q|^{2}\right) q \\
& \frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial \bar{q}^{2}}(q, \bar{q})=f^{\prime \prime}\left(|q|^{2}\right) q^{2} \\
& \frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q^{2}}(q, \bar{q})=f^{\prime \prime}\left(|q|^{2}\right) \bar{q}^{2}
\end{aligned}
$$

Assuming the Iterative Lemma holds up to step $r-1$, then for $\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right) \in \underset{I \in \lambda_{r-1}}{\cup} I$, we have

$$
\left\|\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q \partial \bar{q}}\left(q_{r-1}, \bar{q}_{r-1}\right)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{r-1}}<1,\left\|\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial \bar{q}^{2}}\left(q_{r-1}, \bar{q}_{r-1}\right)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{r-1}}<1,\left\|\frac{\partial^{2} H}{\partial q^{2}}\left(q_{r-1}, \bar{q}_{r-1}\right)\right\|_{\alpha, L_{r-1}}<1
$$

Thus we have

$$
\left|T\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)\right|<\varepsilon \delta_{r}^{-C_{\alpha}} e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}
$$

where $C_{\alpha}$ depends on $\alpha$.
In fact, we can also derive

$$
\left|T\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)\right| \leq e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.2)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}, \text { for } x \neq x^{\prime}
$$

by applying Lemma 2.11 and (1.3.b) $(l \leq r-1)$ inductively.
We impose the following Diophantine condition on the vector $\lambda$ :

$$
\left|k \cdot \lambda-\mu_{n}\right|>\gamma(1+|k|)^{-C}, \quad|k|<N_{r},(n, k) \notin \mathcal{R}
$$

where $C>b+d$. We denote this condition by $D C_{\gamma, C}$, and we can easily derive that

$$
\operatorname{mes}\left\{I_{0} \backslash D C_{\gamma, C}\right\} \lesssim \gamma
$$

Also, note that we have $\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda+O(\varepsilon)$ by solving Q-equations at each step. It follows that

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|k \cdot \lambda^{\prime}-\mu_{n}\right| & >\left|k \cdot \lambda-\mu_{n}\right|-|k \cdot O(\varepsilon)| \\
& >\frac{1}{2} \gamma(1+|k|)^{-C}
\end{aligned}
$$

for $|k|<\gamma^{\frac{1}{2 \kappa}} \varepsilon^{-\frac{1}{2 \kappa}}$. Let $\gamma=\left(\log \log \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)^{-\frac{1}{2}}$, and since $N_{r}=A^{r}<e^{C\left(\log \log \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)^{2}}$, we have

$$
\left\|D_{P, N}^{-1}\right\|<2 \gamma^{-1} N_{r}^{C}<e^{C\left(\log \log \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)^{2}}
$$

For simplicity, we omit the subscripts $q$ and $P$ when there is no confusion in the sequel. Now we use the Neumann argument to estimate the bound of the Green function:

We have

$$
\begin{aligned}
T_{N}^{-1} & =\left(D_{N}-\varepsilon S_{N}\right)^{-1} \\
& =D_{N}^{-1}\left(I-\varepsilon S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\right)^{-1} \\
& =D_{N}^{-1}+\sum_{j=1}^{\infty} \varepsilon^{j} D_{N}^{-1}\left(S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\right)^{j}
\end{aligned}
$$

Notice that

$$
\left\|\left(I-\varepsilon S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\right)^{-1}\right\|<\frac{1}{1-\left\|\varepsilon S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\right\|}<\frac{1}{1-\varepsilon^{1-}}<2
$$

thus we have

$$
\left\|T_{N}^{-1}\right\|<2\left\|D_{N}^{-1}\right\|<4 \gamma^{-1} N^{C}<2 e^{C\left(\log \log \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)^{2}}
$$

Now we consider the off-diagonal decay of $T_{N}^{-1}$. We have

$$
\left|\varepsilon S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)\right|<\varepsilon^{1-}\left|S_{N}\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)\right|<\varepsilon^{1-} \delta_{r}^{-C_{\alpha}} e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}
$$

Thus we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\left(\varepsilon S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\right)^{j}\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)\right| & =\left|\sum_{k_{1}, \ldots, k_{j-1} \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}}\left(\varepsilon S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\right)\left(x, k_{1}\right) \cdots\left(\varepsilon S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\right)\left(k_{j-1}, x^{\prime}\right)\right| \\
& \leq \sum_{k_{1}, \ldots, k_{j-1} \in \mathbb{Z}^{b+d}} \varepsilon^{\frac{1}{4} j}\left(\delta_{r}^{-C_{\alpha}}\right)^{j} e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}} \\
& \leq(2 N)^{(b+d) j} \varepsilon^{\frac{1}{4} j}\left(\delta_{r}^{-C_{\alpha}}\right)^{j} e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}} \\
& \leq\left((2 N)^{b+d} \delta_{r}^{-C_{\alpha}} \varepsilon^{\frac{1}{4}}\right)^{j} e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Since $N_{r}<e^{C\left(\log \log \frac{1}{\varepsilon}\right)^{2}}$, we have

$$
\left(2 N_{r}\right)^{b+d} \delta_{r}^{-C_{\alpha}} \varepsilon^{1 / 4}<\varepsilon^{\frac{1}{8}}
$$

thus

$$
\left|\left(\varepsilon S_{N} D_{N}^{-1}\right)^{j}\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)\right|<\left(\varepsilon^{\frac{1}{8}}\right)^{j} e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}
$$

So for $x \neq x^{\prime}$, we have

$$
\left|T_{N}^{-1}\left(x, x^{\prime}\right)\right| \leq \varepsilon^{\frac{1}{8}} \cdot 2 \gamma^{-1} N^{C} e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}<e^{-\alpha L_{r}^{(0.1)}\left|x-x^{\prime}\right|_{\alpha}}
$$

Thus, we have the bound (5.1), and the measure estimate (5.4) is straightforward to verify.

Thus, the solution $\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda+\varepsilon \varphi_{r}(\lambda)$ of

$$
\left(\lambda_{j}^{\prime}-\lambda_{j}\right) a_{j}-\varepsilon \frac{\widehat{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}\left(q_{r}, \bar{q}_{r}\right)\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)=0, \quad 1 \leq j \leq b
$$

is real.
For measure estimate, we will consider an approximation of $Q$-equations to obtain a semialgebraic description. Since $\left\|q_{r}\right\|_{\alpha, A^{-(r+2) C_{1}}, L_{r}} \ll 1$ for $q_{r}$ on $I \times \mathbb{T}^{b+d}$, where $I \in \Lambda_{r}$, we have that $\frac{\widehat{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}\left(q_{r}, \bar{q}_{r}\right)\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$ is a Gevrey function in $\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$, and

$$
\left\|\widehat{\partial H}_{\bar{q}}\right.\left(q_{r}, \bar{q}_{r}\right)\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)\right\|_{\alpha, A^{-(r+2) C_{1}}} \lesssim 1
$$

Let $I^{\prime} \in \Lambda_{r}^{(1)}$, then the size of $I^{\prime}$ is $A^{-\alpha\left((r+3)^{C_{1}}-(r+3)^{C_{2}}\right)}$. Let $\left(\lambda_{0}, \lambda_{0}^{\prime}\right)$ be the center of $I^{\prime}$ and let $\psi_{p}\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$ be the Taylor polynomial of $\frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial q}\left(q_{r}, \bar{q}_{r}\right)\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)$ of degree $p$ centered at $\left(\lambda_{0}, \lambda_{0}^{\prime}\right)$. Then for $\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right) \in I^{\prime}$ we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
& \left|\frac{\overline{\partial H}}{\partial \bar{q}}\left(q_{r}, \bar{q}_{r}\right)\left(n_{j}, e_{j}\right)\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)-\psi_{p}\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)\right| \\
\leq & C(p+1)!^{\alpha-1}\left(A^{(r+2)^{C_{1}}}\right)^{\alpha(p+1)}\left(A^{-\alpha\left((r+3)^{C_{1}}-(r+3)^{C_{2}}\right)}\right)^{p+1} \\

\leq & C\left((p+1)^{\alpha-1} \cdot A^{-\alpha\left(C_{1}-2\right)\left(r+2\right)^{C_{1}-1}}\right)^{p+1}
\end{aligned}
$$

Take $p+1=2^{r+1} \log \frac{1}{\varepsilon}$, then we obtain

$$
\begin{aligned}

\leq & C A^{-\alpha(r+2)^{C_{1}-1}(p+1)} \\
\leq & \varepsilon \frac{\log A}{\log 1 / \varepsilon} \alpha(r+2)^{C_{1}-1}(p+1) \\
\leq & \varepsilon^{2^{r+1}}
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, at step $r$, we can replace $Q$-equations by

$$
\left(\lambda_{j}^{\prime}-\lambda_{j}\right) a-\varepsilon \psi_{p}\left(\lambda, \lambda^{\prime}\right)=0, \quad 1 \leq j \leq b
$$

We will denote the solution of (5.51) as $\lambda^{\prime}=\lambda+\varepsilon \varphi_{r}^{\prime}(\lambda)$. ### 6.1 Coupling Lemma

In this subsection, we present two coupling lemmas. Here, we denote $c=\frac{1}{\alpha}$, where $\alpha$ is the Gevrey index. Let $T_{\Lambda}$ be the restriction of the matrix $T$ to $\Lambda \times \Lambda$, where $\Lambda$ is a subset of the index set, and we denote $G_{\Lambda}:=T_{\Lambda}^{-1}$. Recall that if

$$
\Lambda=\Lambda_{1} \cup \Lambda_{2}, \quad \Lambda_{1} \cap \Lambda_{2}=\varnothing
$$

where $\Lambda, \Lambda_{1}$ and $\Lambda_{2}$ are finite subsets, then we have the resolvent identity:

$$
G_{\Lambda}=\left(G_{\Lambda_{1}}+G_{\Lambda_{2}}\right)-\left(G_{\Lambda_{1}}+G_{\Lambda_{2}}\right)\left(T_{\Lambda}-T_{\Lambda_{1}}-T_{\Lambda_{2}}\right) G_{\Lambda}
$$

The following coupling lemma is the key improvement that enable us to obtain the quasi-periodic solution with arbitrary Gevrey index $\alpha>1$.

$$

Now we consider the off-diagonal decay. Assume that $|x-y|>M_{1}^{\theta}$. Our goal is to achieve the desired off-diagonal decay by iteratively applying inequality (6.15). The iteration process continues until the distance between $w$ and $y$ becomes less than $2 M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}$, which serves as the termination condition.

In each iteration, the distance between $w$ and $y$ decreases relative to the distance between $x$ and $y$. Specifically, from (6.15), we observe that when the distance between $w$ and $y$ in all dimensions decreases by $2 M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}$, we obtain a decay factor of at least $e^{-M_{1}^{\theta_{3}} c}$. We will analyze the decay in each dimension separately.

Suppose that, in (6.15), for some $j$, the distance $\left|z_{j}-w_{j}\right|<M_{1}^{\theta_{3}}$ is repeated $M_{1}^{\theta-\theta_{1}-\tilde{\delta}}$ times for a small $\tilde{\delta}$. After $M_{1}^{\theta-\theta_{1}-\tilde{\delta}}$ iterations, the repeated application of (6.15) leads to a decay of at least $e^{-M_{1}^{\theta-\theta_{1}-\tilde{\delta}} \cdot M_{1}^{\theta_{3}} c}$, which simplifies to $e^{-(b+d) L M_{1}^{c}}$ under the condition $\theta-\theta_{1}-\tilde{\delta}+\theta_{3} c>c$.

Next, consider the case where $\left|z_{j}-w_{j}\right|<M_{1}^{\theta_{3}}$ occurs fewer than $M_{1}^{\theta-\theta_{1}-\tilde{\delta}}$ times. In this case, for every dimension, there is at most a loss of distance of $M_{1}^{\theta-\tilde{\delta}}$. Without loss of generality, we assume that the distance between $x$ and $y$ in all dimension (i.e., $\left|x_{j}-y_{j}\right|$ ) is greater than $M_{1}^{\theta-\tilde{\delta} / 2}$. Otherwise, the dimension with the greatest distance will provide the decay for those dimensions where the distance is less than $M_{1}^{\theta-\tilde{\delta} / 2}$, with a small reduction in $L$ by $O\left(M_{1}^{-c \tilde{\delta}}\right)$.

Let us now focus on each individual dimension. Take $x_{1}, y_{1}$ for example. Let $R$ denote the distance that contributes to the decay, then we have

$$
R+M_{1}^{\theta-\tilde{\delta}} \geq\left|x_{1}-y_{1}\right|
$$

We refer to the distance that contributes to the decay as the decay distance. For $1 \leq j \leq R / M_{1}^{\theta}$, denote by $l_{j} R$ the sum of the decay distances provided by (6.15) where $j M_{1}^{\theta_{1}} \leq\left|z_{1}-w_{1}\right|<$ $(j+1) M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}$. Denote by $l_{0} R$ the sum of the decay distances provided by (6.15) where $M_{1}^{\theta_{2}} \leq$ $\left|z_{1}-w_{1}\right|<M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}$. Clearly, we have

$$
\sum_{j=0}^{R / M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}} l_{j} \geq 1
$$

Thus, the total decay across iteration is greater than

$$
\begin{aligned}
\frac{l_{0} R}{3 M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}} M_{1}^{\theta_{2} c}+\sum_{j=1}^{R / M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}} \frac{l_{j} R}{(j+3) M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}} j^{c} M_{1}^{\theta_{1} c} & \geq \sum_{j=0}^{R / M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}} l_{j}\left(1-O\left(M_{1}^{-\theta+\frac{3 \tilde{\delta}}{4}+\theta_{1}}\right)\right) R^{c} \\
& \geq\left(1-O\left(M_{1}^{-\theta+\frac{3 \tilde{\delta}}{4}+\theta_{1}}\right)\right) R^{c} \\
& \geq\left(1-O\left(M_{1}^{-\theta+\frac{3 \tilde{\delta}}{4}+\theta_{1}}\right)\right)\left(1-\frac{M_{1}^{c\left(\theta_{1}-\tilde{\delta}\right)}}{\left|x_{1}-y_{1}\right|^{c}}\right)\left|x_{1}-y_{1}\right|^{c} \\
& \geq\left(1-O\left(M_{1}^{-c \tilde{\delta} / 2}\right)\right)\left|x_{1}-y_{1}\right|^{c}
\end{aligned}
$$

The inequality above relies on the facts that

$$
\frac{R}{3 M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}} M_{1}^{\theta_{2} c} \geq R^{c}
$$

and

$$
\frac{j^{c} R}{(j+3) M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}} M_{1}^{\theta_{1} c} \geq\left(1-O\left(M_{1}^{-\theta+\frac{3 \tilde{\delta}}{4}+\theta_{1}}\right)\right) R^{c}
$$

under the assumption

$$
c<\frac{\theta-\frac{\tilde{\delta}}{2}-\theta_{1}}{\theta-\frac{\tilde{\delta}}{2}-\theta_{3}}
$$

The inequality (6.18) follows from

$$
\frac{j}{j+3}\left(\frac{R}{j M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}}\right)^{1-c} \geq 1-O\left(M_{1}^{-\theta+\frac{3 \tilde{\delta}}{4}+\theta_{1}}\right)
$$

which holds for all $j$. Actually, when $j \geq \frac{R}{M_{1}^{\theta_{1}+\frac{2}{4}}}$, we have

$$

$$

and when $j<\frac{R}{M_{1}^{\theta_{1}+\frac{1}{2}}}$, we have

$$
\frac{j}{j+3}\left(\frac{R}{j M_{1}^{\theta_{1}}}\right)^{1-c}>1

We conclude that

$$
\left|G_{\Omega}(x, y)\right|<e^{-\left(L-O\left(M_{1}^{-c \bar{\delta} / 2}\right)\right)|x-y|_{a}}, \text { for }|x-y|>M_{1}^{\theta}

$$

# A A technical proposition about the reality of Fourier coefficients 

Proposition A. 1 (Reality). Let $f \in C^{1}([-1,1])$ be real-valued, and let $q$ be a function defined on $\mathbb{T}^{n}$, with $\hat{q}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}^{n}$. Suppose $\|q\|_{C^{0}\left(\mathbb{T}^{n}\right)}$ is small enough, then $\left(f\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all $k \in \mathbb{Z}^{n}$.

Proof. Since $\hat{q}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$, we know that $(q \bar{q})^{\wedge}(k)=(\hat{q} * \hat{q})(k) \in \mathbb{R}$. Let $\chi$ be a smooth bump function such that $0 \leq \chi \leq 1, \chi=1$ on $\left[-\frac{1}{4}, \frac{1}{4}\right]$ and $\chi=0$ outside $\left[-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]$. If $\|q\|_{C^{0}\left(\mathbb{T}^{n}\right)}$ is small enough, then $(f \cdot \chi)\left(|q|^{2}\right)=f\left(|q|^{2}\right)$. So without loss of generality, we can assume $f$ is periodic with period 1. Since $f$ is real-valued, it is easy to check that the Fourier series of $f$ has the following form:

$$
f(x)=\sum_{j \in \mathbb{Z}} l_{j} \cos 2 \pi j x+m_{j} \sin 2 \pi j x
$$

where $l_{j}, m_{j}(j \in \mathbb{Z})$ are real. Let $f_{n}(x)=\sum_{|j| \leq n} l_{j} \cos 2 \pi j x+m_{j} \sin 2 \pi j x$. Since $f \in C^{1}\left(\left[-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]\right)$, $f_{n}$ converges to $f$ uniformly.

For any $k \in \mathbb{Z}^{n}$, we have

$$
\begin{aligned}
\left|\left(f\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(k)-\left(f_{n}\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(k)\right| & =\left|\int_{\mathbb{T}^{n}}\left(f\left(|q|^{2}\right)-f_{n}\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right) e^{-2 \pi i k x} d x\right| \\
& \leq \int\left|f\left(|q|^{2}\right)-f_{n}\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right| d x \\
& \leq \sup _{x \in \mathbb{T}^{n}}\left|f\left(|q(x)|^{2}\right)-f_{n}\left(|q(x)|^{2}\right)\right| \\
& \leq \sup _{s \in\left[-\frac{1}{2}, \frac{1}{2}\right]}\left|f(s)-f_{n}(s)\right|
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus, $\left(f_{n}\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(k)$ converges to $\left(f\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(k)$ as $n \rightarrow+\infty$ for all $k$. Therefore, it suffices to show that $\left(f_{n}\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all $k$.

To prove $\left(f_{n}\left(|q|^{2}\right)\right)^{\wedge}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all $k$, it suffices to show that $\left(\cos 2 \pi j|q|^{2}\right)^{\wedge}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$ and $\left(\sin 2 \pi j|q|^{2}\right)^{\wedge}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all $k$. Take $\cos 2 \pi j|q|^{2}$ for example. We have

$$
\cos 2 \pi j|q|^{2}=\sum_{n \geq 0} \frac{(-1)^{n}\left(2 \pi j|q|^{2}\right)^{2 n}}{(2 n)!}
$$

Since $\left(|q|^{4 n}\right)^{\wedge}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all $n$ and $k$, we have $\left(\cos 2 \pi j|q|^{2}\right)^{\wedge}(k) \in \mathbb{R}$ for all $k$. Thus, the proof is completed.

abstract:
We investigate the persistency of quasi-periodic solutions to
multi-dimensional nonlinear Schr\"{o}dinger equations (NLS) involving Gevrey
smooth nonlinearity with an arbitrary Gevrey index $\alpha>1$.
  By applying the Craig-Wayne-Bourgain (CWB) method, we establish the existence
of quasi-periodic solutions that are Gevrey smooth with the same Gevrey index
as the nonlinearity.
